page.title: 03Cockerham Saltmarsh Sea Wall
page.content: A new sea wall was built in 1982 as protection, after serious flooding in the 1970's.The worst flood was on 11th November 1977 when 2800 hectares were flooded and a smaller sea wall built by local farmers was destroyed.The new wall runs from the River Cocker to Fluke Hall at Pilling and the main bank is 7500 metres long.It is 7.6 metres high above ordnance datum and cost Â£1.6 million.This was paid for by the Water Authority,the Ministry of Agriculture and local farmers.It enclosed some 270 hectares about half of this in the Cockerham Parish. Wildlife conservation was considered by building ponds for wildfowl and area's were left for the Natterjack Toad.After consruction local farmers were able to drain and reclaim the land protected by the wall,allowing major improvements in productivity.
